Package org.fishwife.jrugged

Provides for straightforward add-ons to existing code to make it more robust and easier to manage.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    CircuitBreakerExceptionMapper<T extends Exception>
    Allows the user to map the standard CircuitBreakerException thrown by a tripped CircuitBreaker into an application specific exception.
    Clock
    Provides the current time.
    ConstantFlowRegulatorExceptionMapper<T extends Exception>
    Allows the user to map the standard FlowRateExceededException thrown by a ConstantFlowRegulator into an application specific exception.
    FailureInterpreter
    A FailureInterpreter is a helper class that can be used by a CircuitBreaker to determine whether a given failure should cause the breaker to trip.
    Initializable
    Clients who use the Initializer should implement this interface.
    MonitoredService
    The MonitoredService interface allows a Service to report its ServiceStatus.
    ServiceWrapper
    Several of the "rugged" code patterns in this library can be used to wrap an existing service in a "decorator" design pattern.
    ServiceWrapperFactory
    A ServiceWrapperFactory is a way to create several related but distinct ServiceWrapper instances.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    CallableAdapter<R>
    Adapter to expose a Runnable as a Callable, with an optional result.
    CircuitBreaker
    A CircuitBreaker can be used with a service to throttle traffic to a failed subsystem (particularly one we might not be able to monitor, such as a peer system which must be accessed over the network).
    CircuitBreakerConfig
    The CircuitBreakerConfig class holds a CircuitBreaker configuration.
    CircuitBreakerFactory
    Factory to create new CircuitBreaker instances and keep track of them.
    CircuitBreakerNotificationCallback
    Allows outside interested parties to register their interest in the state changes of a CircuitBreaker.
    ConstantFlowRegulator  
    DefaultFailureInterpreter
    Trips a CircuitBreaker if the number of failures in a given time window exceed a specified tolerance.
    FlowMeter
    This class uses a raw RequestCounter to compute request rates over time for total rate of request, rate of successful requests, and rate of failed requests.
    Initializer
    An Initializer allows a client to retry failed service initializations in the background.
    LatencyTracker
    This is a statistics wrapper that records the latency of requests, both for successes and failures.
    MovingAverage
    This class implements an exponential moving average, using the algorithm described at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moving_average.
    PercentErrPerTimeFailureInterpreter
    Trips a CircuitBreaker if the percentage of failures in a given time window exceed a specified tolerance.
    PerformanceMonitor
    The PerformanceMonitor is a convenience wrapper for gathering a slew of useful operational metrics about a service, including moving averages for latency and request rate over various time windows (last minute, last hour, last day).
    PerformanceMonitorFactory
    Factory to create new PerformanceMonitor instances and keep track of them.
    RequestCounter
    This is a statistics wrapper that counts total requests, as well as how many succeed and how many fail.
    RolledUpMonitoredService
    A RolledUpMonitoredService provides for grouping MonitoredService instances together into a single system for status reporting purposes.
    SampledQuantile
    The SampledQuantile provides a way to compute approximate quantile measurements across a set of samples reported to an instance.
    ServiceRetrier
    Calls a service multiple times until the call succeeds or the maximum number of tries is exceeded.
    ServiceStatus
    A ServiceStatus is used by a MonitoredService to report its status.
    ServiceWrapperChain  
    SystemClock
    Provides current time as defined by the underlying operating system.
    WindowedEventCounter
    Keeps a count of the number of events that have occurred within a given time window.
  • Enum Summary 
    Enum Description
    CircuitBreaker.BreakerState
    Represents whether a CircuitBreaker is OPEN, HALF_CLOSED, or CLOSED.
    Status
    Various components in the system need to report their status.
  • Exception Summary 
    Exception Description
    CircuitBreakerException
    This exception gets thrown by a CircuitBreaker if a wrapped call is disallowed by a tripped (OPEN) breaker.
    FlowRateExceededException  
    SampledQuantile.QuantileOutOfBoundsException  
    WrappedException  

Package org.fishwife.jrugged Description

Provides for straightforward add-ons to existing code to make it more robust and easier to manage. Although there are several lower-level building block classes here available for custom solutions, most clients will find they can use just the following classes:

  • CircuitBreaker provides a way to wrap a service in a way that provides a bulkhead against system failure; when a remote service fails, further calls to the service are prevented for a period of time to allow the remote service to recover.
  • Initializer provides a way to decouple service construction from initialization/startup and allows the latter to occur in the background, even retrying if initial attempts to initialize fail.
  • PerformanceMonitor provides a way to wrap a service and collect a series of useful statistics about its latency and throughput, even calculating moving averages across different time windows.
  • org.fishwife.jrugged.Monitorable, Status, and org.fishwife.jrugged.RolledUpStatus are related classes that provide a simple RED/YELLOW/GREEN encoding for service health, possibly useful for constructing operational dashboards.

Generally speaking, most of these classes implement a ServiceWrapper interface to allow them to be applied around existing services using the Decorator design pattern. Those classes providing operational information, such as PerformanceMonitor and org.fishwife.jrugged.Monitorable can be wrapped in classes that expose their data to JMX controls or on web-accessible health status pages as desired.

Related Documentation

For overviews, tutorials, examples, guides, and tool documentation, please see:
